data.title: Clean up npm temp folders on CI
data.body: Folders of the style `npm-10200-49dae08c` are filling up our CI machines so delete them all each time a CI build runs since they are leftovers from previous builds and are never reused or needed again.

data.title: Changing the "Soft Tab" setting wasn't effective on already opened documents.
data.body:
And I have to close the current document and then reopen it in order to see the tab=>space changes.

```
$ atom --version
0.188.0
```

data.title: Export File and Directory through require('atom')
data.body:
This exports the pathwatcher File and Directory classes through require('atom').

I think this makes sense since those classes are already publicly documented as part of the Atom platform API, but currently there's no way for a package to require and instantiate them. The alternative is to add the pathwatcher module to my own package, but this seems redundant since File and Directory are already documented as part of the Atom platform. Also since pathwatcher is a native package it's even more problematic then it would be with a normal package.

data.title: Atom Editor Doesn't Come to Foreground
data.body:
Hi,

My OS is Ubuntu 14.10. I use Unity as my window manager. Atom version is 0.188.0. 

If I open a file from Nautilus file manager by pressing "Enter" or by double-clicking, Atom often doesn't come to foreground. (Its icon wobbles in Unity dashboard.) To see it, I have to switch to Atom manually. Only after that, I can work on the file. 

I made some tests. It happens when Atom is already open and if I use Alt+Tab key combination. If I never use Alt+Tab to switch between windows, then there's no problem. Otherwise, first I've to open file, then manually switch to Atom window. Unfortunately It's inefficinet way to work.

What I want is, Atom should always come to foreground, if I open a file. Is there a workaround or a patch for this problem?

Kind regards,
Cagatay

data.title: minor changes in decoration.coffee
:arrow_up: atom-shell@0.22.3
Rename of directory does not reopen saved file in new directory
data.body:
I've noticed that when renaming a directory and having a saved file open in a tab, does not update the file reference, it still points to the old directory? 

Steps to reproduce:

```
mkdir d1
cd d1
touch f1 f2 f3
(open f1 from tree-view)
cd ..
mv d1 d2
```

Result: f1 points to d1

I am on; atom 0.188.0, linux fedora 21

data.title: Allow overlay decorations to break out of the editor; bound overlays to window
data.body:
Here is an overlay outside the editor bounds with a `-250px` `left-margin`:

![screen shot 2015-03-31 at 7 13 04 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/69169/6933331/7e001cfe-d7da-11e4-9b83-4b810b9894fb.png)

Here is autocomplete using the new overlay. Note how it is up against the window, and it is shifted horizontally and flipped vertically to keep within the window.

![autocomplete-recompute-better](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/69169/6933332/8b437e92-d7da-11e4-8e81-8485c5cc1968.gif)
### Notes
- The overlay parent is the `atom-text-editor`. The editor and containing pane are now both `overflow: visible`. This allows the pane item the flexibility to have things jump out if necessary.
- When bumping up against the left or right edge of the window, the overlay will _shift_ horizontally, not flip. This always keeps it in the window frame. Shifting felt more natural than flipping.
- When bumping up against the bottom edge of the window, the overlay will flip. It will not necessarily be always visible in the window frame (due to scrolling), but does its best with the flip.
- A `left-margin` is supported on the overlay. It will take the margin into account when doing the window bounds-checking. Note the blue box in the first image has a `-250px` left margin.
- In the future, it would be nice to allow configuration of the shift or flip, or bounds checking at all, but for right now, keeping it simple.
### TODO
- [x] Make it work
- [x] Clean up the overlay caching :art:
- [x] Move specs to the presenter
- [x] All specs passing

cc @nathansobo @bolinfest

data.title: Sync update of overlay decorations with editor's DOM update/read lifecycle
data.body:
The overlay decoration updates happen out of phase with the editor update/read cycle. See this gif:

![autocomplete-recompute-bad](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/69169/6933057/114d2514-d7d7-11e4-85b2-3083c4c639b3.gif)

Note how the shorter autocomplete list sticks around for a second in the old position before it is remeasured and re-rendered. What's happening is this:
1. type char
2. editor renders
3. the autocomplete suggestion list updates 
4. `pollDOM` picks up the size change, and re-renders :hankey: 

If we can update the autocomplete list in the editor's update cycle, the new size is read immediately, and we get a smoother render:

![autocomplete-recompute-better](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/69169/6933058/1730b00e-d7d7-11e4-9d22-bc39226fe03a.gif)

I've hacked this in like so. In the `text-editor-component`

``` coffee
requestUpdate: =>
    atom.views.updateDocument =>
      @editor.horribleUpdateMethod?()
      @editor.horribleUpdateMethod = null
      @updateSync()
    atom.views.readDocument(@readAfterUpdateSync)
```

In autocomplete suggestion list element

``` coffee
itemsChanged: ->
  atom.workspace.getActiveTextEditor()?.horribleUpdateMethod = =>
    @renderItems()
```
### How even?

Of course, the hack is not ideal, but how would folks feel about some mechanism to allow for synchronizing the editor render with something external?

I like the `atom.views.updateDocument()` method, but I am not guaranteed to get in the same cycle as the editor. Could we provide another method? `editor.onWillUpdateDocument()`? I know we used to have an event similar to this, and it wasnt great as package authors were abusing it.

cc @nathansobo @as-cii

data.title: Stop polling the DOM when the editor does not have focus
data.body: it continues to poll even when the editor window is not focused. This contributes to a constant 1 - 3% CPU on my machine.

data.title: Canceling multiselect should retain first selection, not last
data.body:
Coming from Sublime, I'm expecting that canceling a multiselect retains my original selection, rather than the final match.

**Atom**

![atom-cancel-multiselect](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4323180/6932292/485e2216-d7e5-11e4-9c76-4b7b2748dc2f.gif)

**Sublime**

![sublime-cancel-multiselect](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4323180/6932303/6ecba18a-d7e5-11e4-9457-836342cfc128.gif)

Not that Atom should necessarily behave exactly like Sublime, but I thought it was a difference in behavior that was worth bringing up for discussion.

If the current behavior is intentional, expected behavior, any chance someone could be so kind as to point me in the direction of how I could write a plugin to override this for my own setup? Having a hard time figuring out where the "cancel selection" behavior is defined.

Thanks! :)

data.title: Multiple cursors shuffle order on paste when selecting characters on more than 7 lines
data.body:
![atom-mult-cursor-bug](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/545359/6927209/31fb9628-d7ec-11e4-9f4a-1665f630864f.gif)
Hi! 
I noticed a bug when selecting 7 or more lines with multiple cursors. In the gif above, I press ctrl-alt-down 7 times, then once shift-right to select the numbers, then ctrl-c to copy, then esc to go back to 1 cursor. When I press ctrl-v on an empty line, the just copied numbers are shuffled.

data.title: publish Atom Editor as a Chrome App in the Chrome Web Store
data.body: Should be a simple re-packaging as the app is already natively html, no?

data.title: core should use services when provided
data.body:
When the `web-browser` package is installed the user clearly wants web pages opened internally.  I can only think of one way to handle this situation.
- If a web service is offered then the internal webpage open, like menu help, should use it.  Would  a PR for this be accepted?  
- Does it make sense for core to consume services or should services provided by packages only be used by other packages?
- Is there a better way to handle this?

data.title: Help menu doesn't work if no browser is installed
data.body: None of the Help menu items (except for Release Notes) works if the user does not have a web browser installed. The default on CentOS 7 is not to have a browser. It wouldn't be so bad if at least an error message popped up informing that the user needs a browser. As it is right now, there is no error message, no help, no nothing. It would be nicer if the help was not 100% dependent on an external browser.

data.title: CentOS RPM requires gtk2 GConf2 libXtst RPM dependencies
data.body:
I had to manually install the following RPMs on CentOS 7

  gtk2
  GConf2
  libXtst

to get atom to run without error.  I think they should be added as dependencies in the atom RPM. In addition, I had a font error, but I don't know what is the correct RPM to get a monospaced font.

data.title: Issues when editing .reg files
data.body:
When editing a .reg file, you have to press the **del** key twice to delete a key. This is the same with **backspace**.

Also, when you highlight text, the amount highlighted is half the position of the cursor.

For example, trying to highlight _I am using Atom to edit text_, would only highlight _I am using At_.

Note that typed text after opening the file and before saving isn't affected by this issue.

Produced on Win8.1 running at 4K.

data.title: Highlighting YAML blocks in Pandoc Markdown files
data.body:
Hi,

pandoc parses a YAML block in markdown files to set metadata and template variables. Highlighting in Github Markdown does not work correctly, when I use a YAML block with a multiline entry. The attached screenshots show the behaviour.

In One Light all the rest of the text gets green. I am using Atom 0.188.0

![correct-highlighting](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1416069/6913899/cf4413c2-d785-11e4-8695-e2dbdab03d5d.png)

data.title: Atom toolbar (top) on Windows 8 Surface Pro Looks way too small
data.body: Can there be an option to adjust the toolbar size? This is not the Windows title, that's adjusted easily, nor is it the menu. It's the toolbar at the top and the tabs at the top, and the status bar at the bottom, are all too tiny and cannot be adjusted. (I couldn't find a way to adjust their size).

This error happens when I run atom as regular OR administrative user.
As I cannot install any packages and now I am also unable to install updates I seem to be a bit lost :(. I really want to use your editor, but you just dont let me :).

data.title: Couldn't open tree view
data.body:
Both the shortcut and the menu couldn't open the tree view.
Ubuntu 14.04.2, atom 0.188.0 3/24/2015, 6:05:58 PM

data.title: Predictive Text
data.body:
I'm not sure if this is even a feature, but I wanted to check and see if Atom can do predictive text.

For example, in Sublime, you it guesses what your going to type and allows you to fill in the rest of a long word or phrase by pressing tab. Also (this could be an eclipse feature only, I forget) when I enter a variable name and then hit . or ->  (I'm coding in C) it sometimes knows what types of that variable are and suggests them. Can Atom do this?

I can provide pictures if needed.

data.title: Setting Atom as my default editor in Cyberduck
data.body:
So when Atom installed itself, I have no idea where it placed its files... 
I've been trying to set Atom as my default editor in Cyberduck, the issue is, I can't find the "Atom" file in my computer to select in the file window.

I tried selecting the Atom shortcut that was installed on my desktop, but Cyberduck claims it points to a file called "update" and then refuses to work. I was able to set Cyberduck to work with Sublime, but I can't figure out how to set Atom as my default editor...

Does anyone know how to fix this?

![where](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/10626101/6910174/7ab7866c-d71d-11e4-9735-bdd18a6321a7.png)

data.title: New folders open new windows?
data.body: I saw that this was an issue in 2014. Was it fixed? if so, how do I resolve my problem?
